contentrichtext.text: In [[chemistry]], '''epimers''' are [[Configurational isomer|configurational isomers]] that differ in configuration of only one [[stereogenic center]]. If the compound has more than one stereogenic centre, the epimer is a [[diastereomer]]. Diastereomers are a class of [[stereoisomers]] that are non-superimposable, non-mirror images of one another.<ref>March, Jerry and Smith, Michael B.. March's Advanced Organic Chemistry: ''Reactions, Mechanisms and Structure''. ''6th ed.'' Hoboken, NJ: momo peon & Sons, Inc., 2007.</ref> <ref>{{GoldBookRef | title = epimers | file = E02167}}</ref> When compounds only have one stereogenic centre, the epimer is an [[enantiomer]]. In chemical nomenclature, one of the epimeric pairs is given the prefix '''epi-''' for example in [[quinine]] and ''epi-quinine''. When the pairs are [[enantiomer]]s, the prefix becomes '''ent-'''. == Examples == The [[sugar]]s '''α'''-glucose and '''β'''-glucose are epimers. In α-glucose, the -OH group on the first (anomeric) carbon is in the direction opposite the [[methylene group]] on carbon C-6 (in the [[Cyclohexane conformation#Chair conformation|axial]] position). In β-glucose, the -OH group is oriented in the same direction as the methylene group (in the equatorial position).<ref>[http://www.biotopics.co.uk/as/glucose2.html Structure of the glucose molecule<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> These two molecules are both epimers and [[anomer]]s (as indicated by the '''α'''-glucose and '''β''' designation). {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |[[Image:Alpha-D-glucopyranose-2D-skeletal.png|220px]] || [[Image:Beta-D-glucopyranose-2D-skeletal.png|220px]] |- align="center" |<center>α-<small>D</small>-glucopyranose</center> || <center>β-<small>D</small>-glucopyranose</center> |} The stereoisomers β-<small>D</small>-glucopyranose and β-<small>D</small>-mannopyranose are epimers because they differ only in the stereochemistry at the C-2 position. The hydroxyl group in β-D-glucopyranose is equatorial (in the "plane" of the ring) while in β-D-mannopyranose the C-2 hydroxyl group is [[Cyclohexane conformation#Chair conformation|axial]] (up from the "plane" of the ring). These two molecules are epimers but, because not mirror images of each other, are also not [[enantiomer]]s (enantiomers have the same name but differ in '''<small>D</small>''' and '''<small>L</small>''' classification). They are also not sugar [[anomer]]s, since the wrong carbon is involved in the stereochemistry. {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |[[File:Beta-D-glucopyranose.svg|200px]] || [[File:Beta-D-mannopyranose.svg|200px]] |- align="center" | <center>β-<small>D</small>-glucopyranose </center>|| <center>β-<small>D</small>-mannopyranose </center> |} [[Doxorubicin]] and [[epirubicin]] are two closely related drugs and epimers. {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |[[File:Doxorubicin–epirubicin comparison.svg|456px]] |- align="center" |<center>Doxorubicin–epirubicin comparison</center> |} Other closely related compounds are [[epi-inositol]] and [[inositol]] and [[lipoxin]] and epilipoxin. {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |[[File:Epi-inositol.svg|156px]] || [[File:Myo-inositol.svg|156px]] || [[File:Lipoxin B4.svg|200px]] || [[File:15-epi-lipoxin B4.svg|200px]] |- align="center" |<center>Epi-inositol</center> |<center>Inositol</center> |<center>Lipoxin</center> |<center>Epilipoxin</center> |} ==Epimerisation== Epimerisation is a chemical process where an epimer is transformed into its chiral counterpart. It can happen in [[condensed tannins depolymerisation]] reactions. Epimerisation can be spontaneous (generally a slow process), or catalyzed by enzymes, e.g. the epimerization between the sugars N-acetylglucosamine and N-acetylmannosamine, which is catalyzed by [[RENBP|Renin-Binding Protein]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Stereochemistry]]
